trans-unit.source: Protect an Azure API app
trans-unit.target: Protect an Azure API app

trans-unit.source: Learn how to protect an Azure API app using Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to protect an Azure API app using Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to protect an API app so that only authenticated users can access it.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to protect an API app so that only authenticated users can access it.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial also shows code that you can use in an ASP.NET API app to retrieve information about the logged-on user.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial also shows code that you can use in an ASP.NET API app to retrieve information about the logged-on user.

trans-unit.source: You'll perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: You'll perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Call the API app to verify that it's working.
trans-unit.target: Call the API app to verify that it's working.

trans-unit.source: Apply authentication rules to the API app.
trans-unit.target: Apply authentication rules to the API app.

trans-unit.source: Call the API app again to verify that it rejects unauthenticated requests.
trans-unit.target: Call the API app again to verify that it rejects unauthenticated requests.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the configured provider.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the configured provider.

trans-unit.source: Call the API app again to verify that authenticated access works.
trans-unit.target: Call the API app again to verify that authenticated access works.

trans-unit.source: Write and test code that retrieves claims for the logged-on user.
trans-unit.target: Write and test code that retrieves claims for the logged-on user.

trans-unit.source: For more information about authentication in Azure App Service, see <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about authentication in Azure App Service, see <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial works with the API app that you created in <linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title> and deployed in <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial works with the API app that you created in <linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title> and deployed in <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The simplest way to verify that your API app is publicly accessible is to call it from a browser.
trans-unit.target: The simplest way to verify that your API app is publicly accessible is to call it from a browser.

trans-unit.source: In your browser, go to the [Azure preview portal].
trans-unit.target: In your browser, go to the [Azure preview portal].

trans-unit.source: From the home page click Browse > API Apps and then click the name of the API app you want to protect.
trans-unit.target: From the home page click Browse > API Apps and then click the name of the API app you want to protect.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Browse</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Browse</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select API app</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select API app</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the API App blade, click the URL to open a browser window that calls your API App.
trans-unit.target: In the API App blade, click the URL to open a browser window that calls your API App.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API App blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API App blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add /api/contacts/get/ to the URL in the browser address bar.
trans-unit.target: Add /api/contacts/get/ to the URL in the browser address bar.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your API app's URL is this:
trans-unit.target: For example, if your API app's URL is this:

trans-unit.source: The complete URL would be this:
trans-unit.target: The complete URL would be this:

trans-unit.source: Different browsers handle API calls differently.
trans-unit.target: Different browsers handle API calls differently.

trans-unit.source: The image shows a successful call from a Chrome browser.
trans-unit.target: The image shows a successful call from a Chrome browser.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Chrome Get response</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Chrome Get response</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Save the URL you used; you'll use it again later in the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Save the URL you used; you'll use it again later in the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: When you deployed your API app, you deployed it to a resource group.
trans-unit.target: When you deployed your API app, you deployed it to a resource group.

trans-unit.source: You can add web apps and other API apps to the same resource group, and each API app within the resource group can have one of three accessibility settings:
trans-unit.target: You can add web apps and other API apps to the same resource group, and each API app within the resource group can have one of three accessibility settings:

trans-unit.source: Public (anonymous) - Anyone can call the API app from outside the resource group without being logged in.
trans-unit.target: Public (anonymous) - Anyone can call the API app from outside the resource group without being logged in.

trans-unit.source: Public (authenticated) - Only authenticated users are allowed to call the API app from outside the resource group.
trans-unit.target: Public (authenticated) - Only authenticated users are allowed to call the API app from outside the resource group.

trans-unit.source: Internal - Only other API apps in the same resource group are allowed to call the API app.
trans-unit.target: Internal - Only other API apps in the same resource group are allowed to call the API app.

trans-unit.source: (Calls from web apps are considered external even if the web apps are in the same resource group.)
trans-unit.target: (Calls from web apps are considered external even if the web apps are in the same resource group.)

trans-unit.source: When Visual Studio created the resource group for you, it also created a gateway.
trans-unit.target: When Visual Studio created the resource group for you, it also created a gateway.

trans-unit.source: A gateway is a special web app that handles all requests destined for API apps in the resource group.
trans-unit.target: A gateway is a special web app that handles all requests destined for API apps in the resource group.

trans-unit.source: When you go to the resource group's blade in the [Azure preview portal], you can see your API app and the gateway in the diagram.
trans-unit.target: When you go to the resource group's blade in the [Azure preview portal], you can see your API app and the gateway in the diagram.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Resource group diagram</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Resource group diagram</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To configure your API app to accept only authenticated requests, you'll set its accessibility to Public (authenticated) and you'll configure the gateway to require authentication from a provider such as Azure Active Directory, Google, or Facebook.
trans-unit.target: To configure your API app to accept only authenticated requests, you'll set its accessibility to Public (authenticated) and you'll configure the gateway to require authentication from a provider such as Azure Active Directory, Google, or Facebook.

trans-unit.source: You have now protected the API app from unauthenticated access.
trans-unit.target: You have now protected the API app from unauthenticated access.

trans-unit.source: Next you have to configure the gateway to specify which authentication provider to use.
trans-unit.target: Next you have to configure the gateway to specify which authentication provider to use.

trans-unit.source: Note: If you have a problem logging in when you do the following steps, try opening a private or incognito window.
trans-unit.target: Note: If you have a problem logging in when you do the following steps, try opening a private or incognito window.

trans-unit.source: Open a browser window, and in the address bar enter the URL that calls your API app's Get method, as you did earlier.
trans-unit.target: Open a browser window, and in the address bar enter the URL that calls your API app's Get method, as you did earlier.

trans-unit.source: This time the attempt to access the API app results in an error message.
trans-unit.target: This time the attempt to access the API app results in an error message.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Chrome Get response fail</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Chrome Get response fail</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the browser, go to the login URL.
trans-unit.target: In the browser, go to the login URL.

trans-unit.source: The URL follows this pattern:
trans-unit.target: The URL follows this pattern:

trans-unit.source: You can get the gateway URL from the Gateway blade in the [Azure preview portal].
trans-unit.target: You can get the gateway URL from the Gateway blade in the [Azure preview portal].

trans-unit.source: (To get to the Gateway blade, click the gateway in the diagram shown on the Resource group blade.)
trans-unit.target: (To get to the Gateway blade, click the gateway in the diagram shown on the Resource group blade.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Gateway URL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Gateway URL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The [providername] must be one of the following values:
trans-unit.target: The [providername] must be one of the following values:

trans-unit.source: "microsoftaccount"
trans-unit.target: "microsoftaccount"

trans-unit.source: "facebook"
trans-unit.target: "facebook"

trans-unit.source: "twitter"
trans-unit.target: "twitter"

trans-unit.source: "google"
trans-unit.target: "google"

trans-unit.source: "aad"
trans-unit.target: "aad"

trans-unit.source: Here is a sample login URL for Azure Active Directory:
trans-unit.target: Here is a sample login URL for Azure Active Directory:

trans-unit.source: Notice that unlike the earlier URL, this one does not include your API app name: the gateway is authenticating you, not the API app.
trans-unit.target: Notice that unlike the earlier URL, this one does not include your API app name: the gateway is authenticating you, not the API app.

trans-unit.source: The gateway handles authentication for all API apps in the resource group.
trans-unit.target: The gateway handles authentication for all API apps in the resource group.

trans-unit.source: Enter your credentials when the browser displays a login page.
trans-unit.target: Enter your credentials when the browser displays a login page.

trans-unit.source: If you configured Azure Active Directory login, use one of the users listed in the Users tab for the application you created in the Azure Active Directory tab of the [Azure portal], such as admin@contoso.onmicrosoft.com.
trans-unit.target: If you configured Azure Active Directory login, use one of the users listed in the Users tab for the application you created in the Azure Active Directory tab of the [Azure portal], such as admin@contoso.onmicrosoft.com.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>AAD users</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>AAD users</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Login page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Login page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the "login complete" message appears, enter the URL to your API app's Get method again.
trans-unit.target: When the "login complete" message appears, enter the URL to your API app's Get method again.

trans-unit.source: This time because you've authenticated, the call is successful.
trans-unit.target: This time because you've authenticated, the call is successful.

trans-unit.source: The gateway recognizes that you are an authenticated user and passes your request on to your API app.
trans-unit.target: The gateway recognizes that you are an authenticated user and passes your request on to your API app.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Login completed</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Login completed</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Chrome Get response</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Chrome Get response</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you have enabled the Swagger UI, you can also go to the Swagger UI page now.
trans-unit.target: If you have enabled the Swagger UI, you can also go to the Swagger UI page now.

trans-unit.source: However, you'll see a red ERROR icon at the bottom right corner of the page, and if you click the icon you'll see a message saying that the Swagger JSON file is inaccessible.
trans-unit.target: However, you'll see a red ERROR icon at the bottom right corner of the page, and if you click the icon you'll see a message saying that the Swagger JSON file is inaccessible.

trans-unit.source: This is because Swagger makes an AJAX call without including the Zumo token to try to retrieve the JSON file.
trans-unit.target: This is because Swagger makes an AJAX call without including the Zumo token to try to retrieve the JSON file.

trans-unit.source: This does not prevent the Swagger UI page from working.
trans-unit.target: This does not prevent the Swagger UI page from working.

trans-unit.source: When you log in to the gateway, the gateway sends back an authentication token.
trans-unit.target: When you log in to the gateway, the gateway sends back an authentication token.

trans-unit.source: This token must be included with all requests from external sources that go through the gateway.
trans-unit.target: This token must be included with all requests from external sources that go through the gateway.

trans-unit.source: When you access an API with a browser, the browser typically stores the token in a cookie and sends it along with all subsequent calls to the API.
trans-unit.target: When you access an API with a browser, the browser typically stores the token in a cookie and sends it along with all subsequent calls to the API.

trans-unit.source: So you can see what is happening in the background, in this section of the tutorial you use a browser tool to create and submit a Post request, and you get the authorization token from the cookie and include it in an HTTP header.
trans-unit.target: So you can see what is happening in the background, in this section of the tutorial you use a browser tool to create and submit a Post request, and you get the authorization token from the cookie and include it in an HTTP header.

trans-unit.source: This section is optional: in the previous section you already verified that the API app accepts only authenticated access.
trans-unit.target: This section is optional: in the previous section you already verified that the API app accepts only authenticated access.

trans-unit.source: These instructions show how to use the Postman tool in the Chrome browser, but you could do the same thing with any REST client tool and browser developer tools.
trans-unit.target: These instructions show how to use the Postman tool in the Chrome browser, but you could do the same thing with any REST client tool and browser developer tools.

trans-unit.source: In a Chrome browser window, go through the steps shown in the previous section to authenticate, and then open developer tools (F12).
trans-unit.target: In a Chrome browser window, go through the steps shown in the previous section to authenticate, and then open developer tools (F12).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Go to Resources tab</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Go to Resources tab</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Resources tab of Chrome developer tools, find the cookies for your gateway, and triple-click the Value of the x-zumo-auth cookie to select all of it.
trans-unit.target: In the Resources tab of Chrome developer tools, find the cookies for your gateway, and triple-click the Value of the x-zumo-auth cookie to select all of it.

trans-unit.source: Note: Make sure you get all of the cookie's value.
trans-unit.target: Note: Make sure you get all of the cookie's value.

trans-unit.source: If you double-click, you'll get only the first part of it.
trans-unit.target: If you double-click, you'll get only the first part of it.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the Value of the x-zumo-auth cookie, and then click Copy.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the Value of the x-zumo-auth cookie, and then click Copy.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Copy auth token</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Copy auth token</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Install the Postman extension in your Chrome browser if you haven't done so yet.
trans-unit.target: Install the Postman extension in your Chrome browser if you haven't done so yet.

trans-unit.source: Open the Postman extension.
trans-unit.target: Open the Postman extension.

trans-unit.source: In the Request URL field, enter the URL to your API app's Get method that you used previously, but omit get/ from the end.
trans-unit.target: In the Request URL field, enter the URL to your API app's Get method that you used previously, but omit get/ from the end.

trans-unit.source: Click Headers, and then add an x-zumo-auth header.
trans-unit.target: Click Headers, and then add an x-zumo-auth header.

trans-unit.source: Paste the token value from the clipboard into the Value field.
trans-unit.target: Paste the token value from the clipboard into the Value field.

trans-unit.source: Add a Content-Type header with value application/json.
trans-unit.target: Add a Content-Type header with value application/json.

trans-unit.source: Click form-data, and then add a contact key with the following value:
trans-unit.target: Click form-data, and then add a contact key with the following value:

trans-unit.source: Click Send.
trans-unit.target: Click Send.

trans-unit.source: The API app returns a 201 Created response.
trans-unit.target: The API app returns a 201 Created response.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add headers and body</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add headers and body</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To verify that this request would not work without the authentication token, delete the authentication header and click Send again.
trans-unit.target: To verify that this request would not work without the authentication token, delete the authentication header and click Send again.

trans-unit.source: You get a 403 Forbidden response.
trans-unit.target: You get a 403 Forbidden response.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>403 Forbidden response</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>403 Forbidden response</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this section you change the code in the ContactsList API app so that it retrieves and returns the name and email address of the logged-on user.
trans-unit.target: In this section you change the code in the ContactsList API app so that it retrieves and returns the name and email address of the logged-on user.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the API app project that you deployed in <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title> and have been calling for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the API app project that you deployed in <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title> and have been calling for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Open the apiapp.json file, and add a line that indicates the API app uses Azure Active Directory authentication.
trans-unit.target: Open the apiapp.json file, and add a line that indicates the API app uses Azure Active Directory authentication.

trans-unit.source: The final apiapp.json file will resemble the following example:
trans-unit.target: The final apiapp.json file will resemble the following example:

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses Azure Active Directory as an example.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses Azure Active Directory as an example.

trans-unit.source: For other providers you would use the appropriate identifier.
trans-unit.target: For other providers you would use the appropriate identifier.

trans-unit.source: Here are the valid provider values:
trans-unit.target: Here are the valid provider values:

trans-unit.source: "aad"
trans-unit.target: "aad"

trans-unit.source: "microsoftaccount"
trans-unit.target: "microsoftaccount"

trans-unit.source: "google"
trans-unit.target: "google"

trans-unit.source: "twitter"
trans-unit.target: "twitter"

trans-unit.source: "facebook".
trans-unit.target: "facebook".

trans-unit.source: In the ContactsController.cs file, add a using statement at the top of the file.
trans-unit.target: In the ContactsController.cs file, add a using statement at the top of the file.

trans-unit.source: Replace the code in the Get method with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the code in the Get method with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Instead of the three sample contacts, the code returns contact information for the logged-on user.
trans-unit.target: Instead of the three sample contacts, the code returns contact information for the logged-on user.

trans-unit.source: The sample code uses Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: The sample code uses Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: For other providers you would use the appropriate token name and claims identifier as shown in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: For other providers you would use the appropriate token name and claims identifier as shown in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: For information about Azure Active Directory claims that are available, see <linkText>Supported Token and Claim Types</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about Azure Active Directory claims that are available, see <linkText>Supported Token and Claim Types</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Add a using statement for Microsoft.Azure.AppService.ApiApps.Service.
trans-unit.target: Add a using statement for Microsoft.Azure.AppService.ApiApps.Service.

trans-unit.source: Redeploy the project.
trans-unit.target: Redeploy the project.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio will remember the settings from when you deployed the project while following the <linkText>Deploy</linkText><title></title> tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio will remember the settings from when you deployed the project while following the <linkText>Deploy</linkText><title></title> tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the project, click Publish, and then click Publish in the Publish Web dialog.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the project, click Publish, and then click Publish in the Publish Web dialog.

trans-unit.source: Follow the procedure you did earlier to send a Get request to the protected API app.
trans-unit.target: Follow the procedure you did earlier to send a Get request to the protected API app.

trans-unit.source: The response message shows the name and ID of the identity you used to log in.
trans-unit.target: The response message shows the name and ID of the identity you used to log in.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Response message with logged on user</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Response message with logged on user</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You've seen how to protect an Azure API app by requiring Azure Active Directory or social provider authentication.
trans-unit.target: You've seen how to protect an Azure API app by requiring Azure Active Directory or social provider authentication.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: https://manage.windowsazure.com/
trans-unit.target: https://manage.windowsazure.com/

trans-unit.source: https://portal.azure.com/
trans-unit.target: https://portal.azure.com/
